text: Chrysopilus asiliformis, the 'little snipefly', is a species of 'snipe flies' (family Rhagionidae). ==Subspecies== Subspecies include:BioLib- *Chrysopilus asiliformis var. asiliformis (Preyssler, 1791) *Chrysopilus asiliformis var. meridiomalis Bezzi, 1898 ==Distribution== This widespread species is present in most of Europe.Fauna europaea Chrysopilus asiliformis. Female ==Habitat== This species inhabits various environments, as scrubs, woodland edges, wetlands and gardens.Nature Spot ==Description== The adults grow up to long. This fragile-looking fly shows a slender body. Head, thorax and abdomen are grey dusted, with dark stripes on the abdomen, without bristles The legs are rather long and thin, with brownish-yellow femora. The wings are hyaline with a dark well marked pterostigma. Eyes are greenish.Mark van Veen Chrysopilus of Northwest Europe - Identification key - HCC ==Biology== Adults can be encountered from May through September. The larvae probably develop in soil. ==Bibliography== * Watson, L., and Dallwitz, M.J. 2003 onwards. British insects: the families of Diptera.
